JS's Prototype-based inheritance and classes demystified

October 15, 2015

JavaScript classes are introduced in ECMAScript 6 and are syntactical sugar over JavaScript's existing prototype-based inheritance.

Note: The class syntax is not introducing a new object-oriented inheritance model to JavaScript, so what is happening behind all this new sugar? Let's digg how ES6 classes works compared to the pseudcoclassical subclass pattern we are used to work with within ES5.

Prototype-based inheritance in ECMAScript 5

Let's immagine a simple scenario, where we have a Car class. We want the constructor function to decorate each generated instance, for example by adding a brand property to the car. We also want each instanciated object to have access to some class methods, for example a horn() function.

1 // Constructor function for the Car class.
2 var Car = function(brand){
3   this.brand = brand;
4 };
5 
6 Car.prototype.horn = function(){return 'honk'};

Now, let's add a subClass and let's call it Tesla (being it a truly new type of car, and therefore a subClass of Car). Of course, we want each Tesla to be branded 'tesla' as well, but we also want it to have some unique features, like for example the ludicrousSpeed function.

 1 // Constructor function for the Tesla subClass.
 2 var Tesla = function(){
 3   // Decorates subClass istances with Car properties
 4   // Note: using the contructor call 'new' 
 5   // when invoking a function will result in:
 6   // this = Object.create(Tesla.prototype)
 7   // Allowing to extend this with the properties we 
 8   // definied wihin the Car constructor:
 9   Car.call(this, 'Tesla');
10   // and finally return this;
11 };
12 
13 // To finish the subclass constructor, we want to make
14 // sure that the prototypal chain delegates correctly
15 // to the Car prototype. For that we need to:
16 // 1 - create a new empty object, that 
17 // 2 - will delegate to the Car prototype and 
18 // 3- assign it to the Tesla prototype
19 Tesla.prototype = Object.create(Car.prototype);
20 // We also need to set the constructor property of
21 // the prototype to point back to the Car constructor.
22 Tesla.prototype.constructor = Car;
23 
24 // We can now add shared methods to any Tesla instance,
25 // by adding them to the prototype object following 
26 // the pseudoClassical Pattern: 
27 Tesla.prototype.ludicrousSpeed = function(){return true};

Without all the comments the Tesla subclass constructor should look something like:

1 // Constructor function for the Tesla subClass.
2 var Tesla = function(){
3   Car.call(this, 'tesla');
4 };
5 
6 Tesla.prototype = Object.create(Car.prototype);
7 Tesla.prototype.constructor = Car;
8 
9 Tesla.prototype.ludicrousSpeed = function(){return true};

Running some tests, to make sure that everything works as expected:

 1 var golf = new Car('vw');
 2 
 3 golf.brand; // -> vw
 4 golf.hasOwnProperty('brand'); // -> true
 5 golf.hasOwnProperty('horn'); // -> false
 6 golf.horn(); // -> honk
 7 golf.hasOwnProperty('ludicrousSpeed'); // -> false
 8 golf.ludicrousSpeed(); // throw err 
 9 
10 
11 var modelS = new Tesla();
12 
13 modelS.brand; // -> tesla
14 modelS.hasOwnProperty('brand'); // -> true
15 modelS.hasOwnProperty('horn'); // -> false
16 modelS.horn(); // -> honk
17 modelS.hasOwnProperty('ludicrousSpeed'); // -> false
18 modelS.ludicrousSpeed() // -> true

Classes in ECMAScript 6, or better, Sugar over the ES5 prototype-based inheritance

Now that we did brush up on the pseudoClassical subclass pattern, let see how the previous code will look like in ES6, using the new Class Syntactic sugar. Refer to the code above to better understand what is going on under the hood, it should be pretty self explanatory by now.

 1 // Class Car
 2 class Car {
 3   constructor(brand) {
 4     this.brand = brand;
 5   }
 6 
 7   horn() {
 8     return 'honk';
 9   }
10 }
11 
12 // SubClass Tesla
13 class Tesla extends Car {
14   constructor() {
15     super('Tesla');
16   }
17 
18   ludicrousSpeed() {
19     return true;
20   }
21 }

Running some tests, to make sure that everything works as expected:

 1 var golf = new Car('vw');
 2 
 3 console.log(golf.brand); // -> vw
 4 console.log(golf.hasOwnProperty('brand'));
 5 console.log(golf.hasOwnProperty('horn'));
 6 console.log(golf.horn()); // -> honk
 7 console.log(golf.hasOwnProperty('ludicrousSpeed'));
 8 
 9 
10 var modelS = new Tesla();
11 
12 modelS.brand; // -> tesla
13 modelS.hasOwnProperty('brand'); // -> true
14 modelS.hasOwnProperty('horn'); // -> false
15 modelS.horn(); // -> honk
16 modelS.hasOwnProperty('ludicrousSpeed'); // false
17 modelS.ludicrousSpeed(); // -> true
18 
19 modelS.__proto__ == golf.__proto__ // -> false
20 modelS.__proto__.__proto__ == golf.__proto__ // -> true
21 
22 Car.prototype.horn = function(){return 'LOUDER HONK'};
23 golf.horn(); // -> LOUDER HONK
24 modelS.horn(); // -> LOUDER HONK

To run and test ES6 code on chrome make sure you switch on the harmony setting. To do so, just enter in your chrome address bar the folloing url: chrome://flags/#enable-javascript-harmony.

Note class and super are not yet supported in chrome, therefore you won't be able to fully test this ES6 out of the box. I strongly encourage you to use the babel transpiler, or play with its online REPL

Nick Balestra Software engineer
